In 1981 while  doing research in the UK I visited my grandparents families in County Mayo, Ireland. The poverty was heartbreaking. In 1999 while my daughter was spending a semester abroad at University College Cork, I revisited my Irish family. The old cottage was now an outbuilding and the family was now housed in a new modern house that would make most American farm families proud. My cousin Mary said it was all due to Ireland having joined the EU. 
Now the GDP per capita in Ireland is $78,000, in the USA it is $65,000 and in the UK it is $41,000. Angela Merkel, as a leading member of the Christian Democrats, had in 2005 warned of the dangers of uncontrolled immigration but as Chancellor later refused to agree to any restrictions. Germany, by far, both economically as German exporters gained access to large nearby markets, and politically, as EU membership tied those countries closer to the West, enhancing the buffer between Germany and Russia.  Who absorbed the costs of Eastern expansion?  The U.K., as immigration surged far beyond pre-expansion estimates.  The UK had the most open and flexible labor market and a relatively generous welfare system.  In addition, the English language is the most widely spoken second language all over the world.  When David Cameron went to Merkel and asked for relief in 2016 prior to the referendum, she prioritized German interests in Eastern Europe, where politicians had a strong desire to retain freedom of movement, over British interests in gaining breathing room. Yet culture is seldom as monolithic as people suspect, especially in America where the culture is base on an origin story that embraces otherness and where nearly every person has fairly recent ancestry reflecting origins elsewhere.

Unfortunately, this causes us to sometimes, understandably, attempt to overemphasize something obvious about a person’s identity. So, Pete is gay. Certainly that tells us something about his lived experience, but we shouldn’t allow that bit on of knowledge to make us think that it is his entirety. He is, after all, not only gay, but male, white, Christian, married, a mayor, and so on, and so on. Similarly it is important that white people acknowledge black lived experience, yet both groups also need to remember that black persons also have lived, to one degree or another, many of the central experiences of white culture, and to one extent or another, the opposite.

The ideal is inclusion rather than exclusion. It is common myth that culture is monolithic. In some places it is more so than in others, but it is never completely so. We must always remember to tell ourselves, I’m OK, you’re OK, and accept differences rather than an insist on homogeneity.

Pharm companies have incentive to push their products, so they in a sense bribe doctors to use their stuff; and worse, they have every incentive to price gouge. Mayor Pete wants to use the market that itself is distorted.

Buttigieg understands that progress for marginalized communities is a complex and necessary priority, and he has plans to expand opportunities for these communities.

In 1969 I was studying at Cambridge University in England. My home college in Minnesota paid my school expenses. I opened a deposit account in the local Lloyd’s of London to keep my personal money safe. My parents had their bank wire transfer a small allowance for me regularly. It was a 3-day “bank holiday.” I went to Lloyd’s to withdraw funds for the weekend; my rent and two meals per day were provided, but I would need some extras spending money. I knew there wasn’t much in my account, and I needed to keep that deposit to hold my account open. My parents’ wire transfer, of $50 (it was 1969!), would have come through. But it didn’t. There was some problem with the wire. So...no funds available. Like the naive 20-year-old that I was, I plead my case to the teller. So sorry, was the reply, you will have to wait. I returned to my student digs and figured I could stretch my remaining few pounds. A short time later, my landlady called me downstairs. At the door was another teller from Lloyd’s. Handing me a ten pound note, he said he overheard my attempted transaction, and, having recently been a student himself, on a strict budget, he wanted to help. He said he had checked my account and saw the regular wire transfers, and that I could just repay him the following week, which I did. It was an act of kindness I remember to this day. As far as I know, no one got in trouble. U. S. Bank should be ashamed.
